The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a major topic of current research. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. The main result is a characterization of the category of Hilbert spaces and continuous linear operators. This provides a categorical framework for the theory of quantum states.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zinc is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of zinc inhibition of the Hv1 channel. We find that zinc binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the zinc-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how zinc inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of a growing population. To meet this challenge, we need to increase crop yields by 7% per year for the next 25 y. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially. These results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant African LMH species. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption inferred from mean sequence relative read abundance ranged from >99% (plains zebra) to <1% (dik-dik). Grass RRA was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of size-matched grazers—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, and many are anticipating difficulties accessing the CARES Act. We also find that businesses that received loans from the CARES Act were more likely to survive the crisis than businesses that did not. However, the effects of the loans on business resilience are likely to be small. Our results suggest that the CARES Act may have been too slow to respond to the crisis and that the program could have been designed to provide more support to businesses that need it most.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This study is of great importance to the scientific community and to society as a whole.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The age of the solar system is a key parameter for the understanding of the formation of the solar system. In this study, we determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. The grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are important for the understanding of the formation of the solar system. They also provide constraints for the formation of the solar system. The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded dramatically. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could increase by 1 million more motorized vessels by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In humans, it is the defining characteristic of the human species. In other species, it is a trait that has been shaped by natural selection. In this study, we explore the factors that affect reproductive output in mammals. We find that the most important factor is the amount of energy available to the mother.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. Here, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotective effects. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA. This would be the first disease-modifying therapy for MSA. The results also suggest that caspase-1 inhibitors could be a promising therapeutic approach for other α-synucleinopathies. This hypothesis will need to be tested in future studies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also the first line of defense against pathogens and debris. To control each function, the endothelium is equipped with a network of specialized cells that are able to detect specific stimuli. This network is composed of clusters of cells that are connected to each other by a network of communication links. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. This work provides a better understanding of the communication network and its role in the control of endothelial function. It also provides a foundation for future studies of the network and its role in the development of cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are critical for understanding the spread of the disease, tracking the impact of public health interventions, and making informed decisions about the future course of the pandemic. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API is a resource that we hope will empower researchers, policy makers, and the general public to make better decisions about the pandemic.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate, blood pressure, and muscle contraction. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in human health and disease. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is not fully understood, and there is a need to identify new classes of molecules that could be used as therapeutics. Here, we identify a number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the gastrointestinal tract of herbivores. These fungi are a potential source of new classes of molecules that could be used to study the role of the microbiome in health and disease.

Anxiety is a major risk factor for social disorders, yet the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate in a social encounter with a low-anxious rat. We identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region involved in the regulation of social behavior. We further show that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Finally, we demonstrate that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and that it is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with programmable responses is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple material phases to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general framework for the design of programmable mechanical structures. It is expected to inspire the development of new materials and structures for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the lifespan of humans and other mammals. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of evolution. The hemoglobin system is under the control of a complex regulatory network. Here we demonstrate that the IGF2BP1 protein, a component of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway, is a key regulator of the hemoglobin system in humans.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite advances in cancer treatment, many patients do not respond to therapy, and the majority of patients succumb to the disease. Cancer is a heterogeneous disease, and the mechanisms of resistance to therapy are complex and often unknown. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to cancer therapy, which is common in many cancers. We found that cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway are resistant to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We also found that this resistance is mediated by a mechanism involving the activation of the mTORC1 signaling axis and the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Finally, we showed that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These results provide a mechanism of resistance to cancer therapy and a strategy for overcoming this resistance. This strategy may be applicable to other forms of cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The most common treatment for hypertension is the use of drugs that block the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2). However, the use of these drugs is limited by the development of side effects. Here, we show that the three major classes of LCCBs activate the store-operated Ca2+ channel (SOCC) in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs). Our findings reveal a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through the activation of the store-operated Ca2+ channel. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of the store-operated Ca2+ channel are elevated. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension. (PsycINFO Database Record

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The predicted best candidate is more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin. The design strategy presented here can be applied to other antibiotic classes. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics. Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is large, and the network architecture is complex. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and is easier to train and apply. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales, and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting network is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The network architecture is simple and easy to implement, train, and apply. The network architecture is also able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing networks for several segmentation problems. The network architecture is applicable to many other problems. The code is available at this https URL .

The climate of the tropics is a key driver of the evolution of life on Earth. The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after the MPT. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin and delays the circadian clock, which may have important implications for sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The cause of the abrupt climate change at the end of the last ice age is one of the most important questions in science today. One hypothesis is that one or more bolide impacts triggered the climate change. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the YDB samples is consistent with terrestrial sources. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the YDB spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the spherules and their leachates are often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the YDB spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of T cell activation, but its specific function in the development of autoimmunity and in different systemic diseases remains to be determined. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice resulted in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 is a key regulator of T cell activation and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity and in different systemic diseases remains to be determined. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, the major component of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetle herbivory was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. These results provide insights into the evolution of the most speciose group of animals. (Less)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also have broader implications for the development of other protein-based therapeutics. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules, such as enzymes, to improve their performance. Our algorithm can also be extended to other applications, such as drug discovery and protein design.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. They also suggest that the benefits of larger populations may be contingent on the amount of variation in the population, and on the working memory of the participants. These results have implications for the design of experiments that investigate the evolution of culture. (Less)

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk, whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. APOE is also a major protein in astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that participates in normal synapse pruning and turnover. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. We also found that APOE alleles are highly associated with the accumulation of complement component C1q in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic synapse pruning. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis may help to explain the increased AD risk associated with APOE4. These studies also suggest that APOE may be a therapeutic target

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,700 km in diameter and 1,300 km in radius. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3. The inner core is thought to have formed when molten iron cooled below the melting point. However, the nucleation mechanism of the stable, hexagonal, close-packed (hcp) phase of iron, which is the main component of the inner core, has not been well understood. We demonstrate that the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hcp phase under inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. View Full-Text

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the underlying mechanisms are not. Here, we show that the brain reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who are more likely to be irritable, anxious, and addicted. These findings suggest that the reduced reactivity to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are poorly understood. Here, we use a large-scale, integrative modeling approach to show that the most powerful deep learning models for natural language processing achieve state-of-the-art performance on a key task by predicting nearly 100% of the variance in the brain’s activity patterns when shown human sentences. The models’ neural fits generalize across datasets and imaging modalities, and model architecture appears to contribute to this generalization. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the language comprehension system may be more similar to other visual systems than previously thought. This work may help to inform the design of future neuroimaging and deep learning studies of language. (Less)

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still unclear whether the success of DL is due to its ability to find good solutions or its ability to find good solutions in a stable way. In this paper, we prove that there are many well-conditioned problems in science and engineering where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a fundamental result that will help us understand the limits of the stability of NNs and the limits of the algorithms that train them.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a scientific scandal. The scientific community is increasingly using the classic 1972 experiment by Daniel Kahneman, Joel Z. Buchman, and Paul J. Kihlstrom to argue that people’s inability to understand exponential growth is the main reason for the pandemic. However, the experiment’s design is flawed in multiple ways. This article discusses the flaws and their implications for the study of human judgment and decision-making. It also discusses the implications of the study’s flaws for the interpretation of the results.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause different forms of the disease. The two bacteria are very similar, but they are not the same. We sequenced the genome of a leprosy biopsy from a patient in Mexico, and compared it with the genome of the other bacteria. We found that the two bacteria are very similar, but they are not the same. This suggests that they are still evolving and that they may have different pathogenic potential. This study also shows that the two leprosy bacteria are not the same, and that they are still evolving. This is important because it helps us understand the evolution of leprosy. (Less)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two concepts that are most difficult to study in quantum systems. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is a major step toward a complete understanding of the interplay between entanglement and thermodynamics.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. To control the pandemic, a large-scale vaccination program is needed. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is highly attenuated and can be manufactured at large scale. This vaccine candidate is expected to be a valuable addition to the global vaccination effort.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. Here, we describe a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-to-human transmission in the history of plague. Our results suggest that the spread of plague in Europe was not only driven by rats but also by humans. This study also provides a framework for studying the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of other diseases.

The evolution of brain size is a major topic of interest in neuroscience. However, the evolution of brain function is more difficult to study. Here, we use the largest dataset of its kind to show that the evolution of brain function is not only different from that of brain size but also more complex. We show that the evolution of brain function is characterized by four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endothermic lineages.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study also provides a mechanistic basis for the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers. This may have implications for the use of TRAP1 inhibitors in cancer therapy. (PsycINFO Database Record

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The disassembly process is controlled by the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. These proteins are the main regulators of actin filament disassembly. However, how they do so remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that mechanical tension has no effect on ADF/cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We propose that this ADF/cofilin-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. A consequence of this mechanism is that cross-linked filament networks are severed far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. This work provides a new understanding of the action of ADF/cofilin and its role in cell mechanics

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many beverages and foods, is a major contributor to the rising epidemic of obesity. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been systematically studied. In this study, we show that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite and a stronger trigger of food cravings than glucose. Understanding the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may help to identify new targets for obesity prevention and treatment. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the history of the island in a fine-grained way. We find that Madagascar was settled by a mixture of people from Africa and Asia, with a sex bias in the recent history of the island. The recent history of the island is also reflected in the genetic structure of the population, which is influenced by geography. These results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar and its people. They also provide a framework to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. (Less)

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which has been observed in laboratory experiments but is controversial in the real world. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not interacting in person. This work suggests that in-person interaction is not necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that the influence of others’ emotions may be stronger than previously thought.

The ribosome is a complex machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into proteins. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only sequences that the ribosome reads. There are many other RNA sequences that the ribosome reads, including pseudouridine (Ψ), which is a common modification in messenger RNA coding regions. We show that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter the rate of protein synthesis and the rate of protein translation. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can alter the speed of protein synthesis and the rate of protein translation. This study provides insight into how mRNA sequences can be modified to alter protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that higher worthwhile ratings are associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. Longitudinally, worthwhile ratings predict positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes independently of baseline levels. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. They also highlight the importance of the subjective experience of worthwhile activities in the maintenance of health and well-being across the life course. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a major theme in the history of life. We use a quantitative analysis of the fossil record and extant data to test hypotheses for the drivers of this pattern. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These results are consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium. This study provides a quantitative test of the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium and a framework for understanding the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals. This framework may also be applicable to other aquatic organisms. (Less)

The common cold is one of the most common and most disruptive diseases in the world. The mechanisms that allow the virus to replicate preferentially at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity are not well understood. We show that the mouse airway cell is a useful model for studying the mechanisms of temperature-dependent rhinovirus replication. We demonstrate that the mouse airway cell is a useful model for studying the mechanisms of temperature-dependent rhinovirus replication.

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to detect the presence of surfaces. This mechanism is important for the pathogen’s ability to attach to surfaces, which is a critical step in the infection process. The results support a mechanochemical model where the mechanical activity of type IV pili is sensed by a chemosensory system, which in turn regulates the activity of type IV pili. This study thus provides a new example of how bacteria use the mechanical activity of their surface adhesins to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Understanding how bacteria sense and respond to their environment is important for understanding how they adapt to their environment and cause disease. It may also lead to the development of new antibacterial strategies.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the quality of global water resources is largely unknown. We provide the first global assessment of the risk of pesticide contamination of surface water and sediments. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. We also show that the use of newer-generation insecticides increases the risk of pesticide contamination of water resources. Thus, the use of pesticides in agriculture needs to be reduced worldwide.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the world, and the animal world is no exception. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. Our findings highlight the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study also provides a unique opportunity to study the role of wildlife in the spread of the virus. The results of this study will help to inform the development of effective strategies to mitigate the spread of the virus in both humans and wildlife. This study also highlights the importance of a coordinated and collaborative effort among different disciplines, including virology, epidemiology, and wildlife biology. (Less)

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins in the brain. The exact cause of AD is unknown, but it is believed to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we show that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain leads to the production of inflammatory factors by neurons, which in turn, activate microglia, the brain’s immune cells. These results suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain may be a key factor in the initiation of AD. This study may lead to the development of new treatments for AD.

The domestication of chickens (Gallus gallus domesticus) is traditionally dated to the second millennium B.C.E. in the Southern Levant. However, the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the region is still missing. Here we present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread at that site. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. The folding of a protein is a complex process that involves the formation of a series of intermediates. The intermediates are not the same for all proteins, but the intermediates are important for understanding the folding process. The intermediates are also important for understanding the role of mutations in the folding process.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs is also activated by stress. This enzyme, which is normally inactive, is able to deprotect Np4-capped RNAs, which are otherwise resistant to decapping, and is able to do so more rapidly than other capped RNAs. These findings suggest that the activation of this enzyme may be a mechanism for regulating the expression of genes in response to stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of the disease. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine, a major amino acid in the diet, is a key molecule in the regulation of the immune system during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is a promising molecule to restore the immune system function in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of sepsis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The biomass of the biosphere is the main component of the global carbon cycle. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the terrestrial biomass is about two orders of magnitude higher than that of the marine biomass. View Full-Text

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature, such as earthquakes, avalanches, or forest fires, where the system is in a critical state and the dynamics are characterized by a power-law distribution. SOC is also a paradigm in physics, where a model, the so-called sandpile model, was introduced. In this paper, we study the sandpile model in the continuum limit and show that it exhibits SOC behavior. This is a major step forward in understanding the nature of SOC.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its mechanical properties are limited. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that its electronic properties can be tuned continuously. We also show that diamond can be transformed into graphite, which is a stable phase. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide a platform for machine learning of the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. This work is expected to advance the understanding of the properties of diamond and its applications. It is also expected to inspire the development of other materials with unique properties.

The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants and animals has led to the development of a new class of plant-derived biofungicides. However, the mode of action of these peptides is not well understood. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide from Medicago truncatula, and demonstrate that it is a potent fungicide against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also show that the peptide binds to bioactive phosphoinositides in germlings, and induces reactive oxygen species and cell death. This work provides a structural basis for the mode of action of this class of peptides, and opens up a new avenue for the development of plant-derived biofungicides. The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the evolution of sex. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the male–female axis is a dynamic system, and that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of sperm and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping to prevent bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause a common disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can switch the VWF A1 domain to a second state with faster binding, providing a mechanism for the observed pathophysiology. The force-dependent switching is consistent with the observed effects of VWD mutations. The force-dependent switching is consistent with the observed effects of VWD mutations.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has only recently begun to be explored. This study is a major step forward in the study of the human virome, and provides a comprehensive resource for the study of viruses in the human microbiome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI process. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to investigate the ACI process. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. The temperature of the Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature of the early Earth is inferred to have been much higher than the present, but the extent to which this temperature has changed over geological time is unknown. Here, we use the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes to infer the temperature of the Earth’s surface at the time of fossilization. Our results suggest that the temperature of the Earth’s surface decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main ion conduits in the cell. They regulate ion flow by opening and closing their pore gates. Ion channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help to understand the BK channel’s unique properties and may provide a basis for the development of new drugs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 128 million cases and 755,000 deaths in 2015. The parasite uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC), the host cell in which it replicates. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses the erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) to alter the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work could lead to the development of new antimalarial drugs that target the parasite’s physical interactions with the host cell. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its mechanical properties are limited. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that its electronic properties can be tuned continuously. We also show that diamond can be transformed into graphite, which is a stable phase. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide a platform for exploring the relationship between mechanical properties and electronic properties of materials. This work is expected to advance the development of diamond-based technologies.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. The brain is thought to build a hierarchical structure of sentences, but there is no direct evidence for this hypothesis. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Moreover, the model of phrase construction provided a better fit than probability-based models at most superior temporal and inferior frontal sites. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of sentence processing may be a general feature of language comprehension. (PsycINFO Database Record)

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in the development of many tissues. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level but also genetically redundant. We also show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the Wnt signal. This study provides a deeper understanding of the mechanism of the Wnt signaling pathway and may help to elucidate the mechanism of tissue-specific regulation of redundant genes.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region for the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We found that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr), which in turn projects to the LH. We also found that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of the LH, peri-LH, or VTA. These results suggest that this circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Symbiotic associations between plants and bacteria are essential for the growth of most plants on Earth. However, the majority of these associations are not beneficial to the plant, as the bacteria fix little nitrogen (N2). We have developed a system that allows the plant to control the activity of the nitrogenase enzyme, which fixes the N2. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also represents a step toward the development of a sustainable agriculture that can meet the needs of a growing population. (Show more)

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to incentivize community-based monitoring, but the effectiveness of these programs is unknown. We study a community monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. Our findings have implications for the design of forest monitoring and conservation programs in the Amazon and beyond.

The ability to hear is fundamental to all animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. The health and climate impacts of air pollution are well known, but the combined effects of fossil-fuel-related emissions and anthropogenic aerosols on global climate are not. We estimate that a phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources can save 3.61 million lives per year and restore rainfall patterns in densely populated regions. This would also limit global warming to 2 °C. The health benefits are even larger if we additionally consider the effects of nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Our results show that the health and climate impacts of air pollution are strongly coupled. Therefore, a global effort is needed to reduce air pollution.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The need for a global vaccine supply is urgent, and the development of a vaccine based on the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein is a promising approach. Here, we report the design and characterization of an engineered RBD that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response. This engineered RBD may be used to develop vaccines that can be manufactured globally at low cost.

The ligand–receptor interaction between ALKALs and FAM150s/AUGs is implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric cancer of neural crest-derived tissues. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKals activate zebrafish Ltk and human ALK in vitro and in vivo. We also show that the three zebrafish ALKals are required for the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. Finally, we show that the loss of zebrafish ALKals leads to the loss of iridophores in zebrafish larvae and adults. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the ligand–receptor interaction between ALKALs and FAM150s/AUGs and the involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. These findings are important for understanding the role of ALKALs in cancer and pigment cell development. They also provide a zebrafish model system for studying the function of ALK/FAM150s/AUGs in neural crest development. This study also provides a foundation for studying the ligand–receptor interaction between ALKALs and FAM150s/AUGs in other organisms.

The emergence of plague as a major human pathogen is a well-documented event in history, but the details of its early evolution remain unclear. Here, we present 17 genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age across Eurasia, providing a more complete picture of the evolution of plague during this period. We find that the emergence of plague was a gradual process, with a single lineage evolving over millennia. We also find evidence of the spread of plague to new regions, including the Mediterranean, which was previously unknown. These findings provide insights into the origins and spread of plague, which may have important implications for understanding the spread of disease throughout human history. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings also have implications for the study of gender, race, and class in the United States.

The management of agricultural systems has a major impact on soil organic carbon (SOC) stocks. However, the effects of different management practices on SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated fractions are highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated fractions. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a pathway for climate-smart agriculture. This study also highlights the importance of long-term field experiments to understand the complex interactions between management practices and soil properties. (Less)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of zoonotic spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a large-scale virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of zoonotic potential can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work is a step toward a more informed and effective response to future viral threats.

Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie this trait are poorly understood. Here, we identify a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin, as the main contributor to the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus. We also identify the red pigment in the nectar of hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae, providing evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a widespread and convergently evolved trait that is likely to be driven by a small number of compounds. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait that is essential for plant reproduction. (Less)

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th centuries AD. We show that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestries of women are very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we show that women with artificial skull deformations had a genetic ancestry that was very different from that of other women. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The global spread of infectious diseases is a major public health concern. The emergence of new pathogens, such as the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has been particularly challenging. The rapid identification of pathogens is critical for the development of appropriate public health response. We describe the use of a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify pathogens in a large cohort of febrile patients in Cambodia. The results provide a comprehensive picture of the pathogen landscape in this region and reveal the importance of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. This study demonstrates the feasibility of pathogen surveillance using mNGS in resource-scarce settings and the potential for rapid deployment of public health response. This approach can be applied to other regions and settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and develop appropriate public health response. (Less)

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with the PCNA sliding clamp while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the mechanism of lagging strand DNA replication. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In the RNA world hypothesis, the first form of life was RNA-based, but the evolution of proteins led to the current form of life. In this paper, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. This work represents a major step toward the realization of the RNA world hypothesis.

We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the residents.
