Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but its high toxicity to eukaryotic cells has led to the development of diverse mechanisms for its homeostasis. In this study, we demonstrate that the xan BGC of Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a copper-binding isocyanide compound that is secreted into the environment. The presence of this compound in the environment suggests that the xan BGC is involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis. The ability of xanthocillin to inhibit the activity of laccase, a key enzyme in the degradation of lignin, suggests a role for this compound in the regulation of interactions with other microbes. The presence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for this pathway in the regulation of copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and interactions with other microbes. (Show more)

The formation of silica-rich minerals in a sedimentary environment is rare on Earth and on Mars. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals and the amorphous silica, and is derived from a silicic volcanic source. The amorphous silica is derived from multiple aqueous solutions, and the mixed-cation salts and oxides are derived from multiple aqueous solutions and/or their diagenesis products. The diagenesis of the amorphous silica and mixed-cation salts is consistent with the formation of the rock in a lacustrine environment.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, which are the world’s largest terrestrial carbon sinks. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new conditions. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the function of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease remains unclear. Here, we show that Th17 cells can directly contribute to colitis pathogenesis by inducing the development of Th1-like cells. In addition, we show that Th17 cells can support the development of Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These results suggest that Th17 cells are important mediators of inflammatory bowel disease pathogenesis. Furthermore, our results suggest that the development of Th17 cells and the development of Th1 cells may be separable events in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease. This may have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the most common cause is a large expansion of a single nucleotide in the gene for the RNA binding protein FUS. We now show that induced astrocytes derived from ALS patients are toxic to motor neurons, and that this toxicity is mediated by the FUS mutation. This work provides a platform for rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify therapies for ALS. It also provides a model for the use of induced pluripotent stem cells in the study of other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays an important role in the transmission of human pathogens. We now show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of Anaplasma to infect the vector. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector to enhance transmission. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of vertebrates. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is poorly understood because of the limited known diversity of early branching members of the clade Pygostylia. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of the atmosphere. In this paper, we show that the atmosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This phenomenon is called color polymorphism. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green color in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. These proteins are most similar to human alpha-1-antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of color polymorphism in vertebrates. It also provides a tool for the study of the function of serpin family proteins. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is enriched in cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. Thus, our results suggest that hypoxia induces ALKBH5, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, which is enriched in cancer stem cells. This may contribute to the maintenance of cancer stem cells in hypoxic tumors. Our findings may have implications for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be applied to other historical documents to help resolve the long-standing controversy over the use of fetal animal skins in parchment. (Less)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing and duration of the extinction, coupled with the timing of the recovery, provide a unique window into the processes that led to the extinction and the processes that controlled the recovery. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery, which will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This work will also establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. This work will provide a better understanding of the causes of the extinction and the processes that controlled the recovery, which will improve our ability to predict the potential for future extinction. (Less)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract. IBD is a heterogeneous disease, and the exact pathogenesis is still unclear. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the pathogenesis of IBD. RORα is a transcription factor that regulates the expression of genes involved in inflammation. We found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our results suggest that therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including IBD. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the two most common forms currently circulating in the United Kingdom and the United States. We find that the G614 mutant spike is more open and may facilitate binding to the receptor, ACE2. These results suggest that the G614 mutant spike may be more infectious.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir (1981) for finite games.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. These findings highlight the importance of addressing structural inequalities in order to achieve health equity. (PsycINFO Database Record

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are the starting point for the study of chemical reactions, chemical bonding, and chemical reactions. In this work, we study the evolution of chemical properties under pressure, which is one of the most important phenomena in the Earth’s mantle and in the universe. We show that the chemical properties of atoms change under pressure, and we provide a predictive model for the evolution of chemical properties under pressure. Our results have implications for the study of the chemical evolution of the universe.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its role in climate change is poorly understood. We quantify the effect of fire on climate change under historical and future climate and human demography. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may enhance land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our results have implications for understanding the role of fire in climate change and for the management of fire regimes.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major contributor to host health and metabolism. However, the mechanisms by which the host regulates the composition of this community are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiotic luminescent bacterium is a key factor in the maintenance of the symbiosis. This glycan is provided only at night, when the host is quiescent, and its catabolism is required for the host to maintain a healthy symbiosis. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of the gut microbiota and the potential for glycans to be used as a tool in the study of host–microbe interactions. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify topics in the narratives of the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This work is important for understanding the content of text data, and for many applications of text analysis.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. However, this assumption is based on a single hypothesis, which has not been tested. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the introduction of the disease into Europe was not a single event, but rather a series of events, each of which was followed by a period of adaptation of the disease to the local environment. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the spread of the disease in Europe. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play an important role in the ecosystem. However, they are also a major source of food for sea stars, which are a major predator in the marine ecosystem. In the Northeast Pacific, asteroids are currently experiencing a mass mortality event, which is associated with a virus. We show that the virus is the most likely cause of the disease and that it has been present in the ecosystem for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides a proof of principle for the use of antibody-based therapies in AML. The results also provide a foundation

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the history of the island in a fine-scale. We find that Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We find that Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate its expression.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. (Less)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We propose a method to convert the original categorical data into a continuous probabilistic variable that is better suited for quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting index is robust across crops, exhibits long-term stability, and has nation-wide validity. We also demonstrate how the index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed method can be applied to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the status of other natural resources.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to store and integrate information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the passage of time. We show that this mechanism is suitable for binding linguistic features over time, and it can be used to integrate information over time in sequence processing. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The origin of plastids and the evolution of their genomes are among the most fundamental questions in biology. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of life on Earth. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the relaxation of functional constraints is linked to the establishment of a parasitic lifestyle. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water availability in South Africa. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in the region. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 Cape Town drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for water resource management and climate change adaptation in the region. (Abridged)

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster proteins, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. These results indicate that Ycf54 is a cyclase subunit in oxygenic phototrophs, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also a major cause of secondary damage in autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of MS. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1). Here, we report that ASK1 is required for neuroinflammation in EAE. We found that ASK1 is required for the activation of microglia and astrocytes, which are the main source of neuroinflammation in EAE. ASK1-deficient microglia and astrocytes have reduced proinflammatory properties, which results in a reduction of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the mechanisms of neuroinflammation in EAE. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. Our results suggest that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions will continue to increase with additional warming. This conclusion is important for understanding the causes of the 2012–2014 drought and the likelihood of future droughts. It also has implications for water management, ecosystem management, and climate adaptation.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and a potential target for drug development. It also provides a general framework for understanding the function of other memory-related behaviors. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is the first to our knowledge to examine the prevalence of negativity biases in a large, representative sample of the world’s populations. Results show that, on average, people around the world are more likely to react negatively to news content than positively. This work also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (SO) cycle is a highly regulated pathway that plays a critical role in many cellular functions. Dysregulation of the SO cycle can lead to severe diseases, such as congenital myopathy and immune dysfunction. Here, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) and the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that result in constitutive activation of the SO cycle and bleeding diathesis. These data expand our understanding of the molecular function of the SO cycle, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also highlights the importance of the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 in the regulation of the SO cycle. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, indicating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may help to identify potential therapeutic targets. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the mechanisms that facilitate the emergence of zoonotic viruses from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein, which we named MTX (for immunosuppressant), inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of viral spillover from bats to humans. (Show more)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of the one-carbon unit pool, which is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and used it to identify a cancer cell-line screen. We show that formate, a one-carbon donor, is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in cancer cells. However, formate is toxic to a subset of B-cell cancer cells, which are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity for glycine import. We show that formate toxicity is rooted in defective glycine import in these cells. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of B-cell cancer. These results provide a rationale for the use of formate as a rescue of SHMT inhibition in cancer cells, and for the use of glycine import as a therapeutic target in B-cell cancer. These findings have implications for the treatment of cancer, and for the use of formate as a rescue of SHMT inhibition in cancer cells.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we observe that the inclusion bodies result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study suggests that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS results from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This may be a general phenomenon in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The study of the early evolution of the flowering plants is hampered by the lack of fossils. Here we present a detailed study of the early evolution of the flowering plants, based on the study of a fossil plant from the Cretaceous period.

The evolution of viruses is often studied using genetic sequences from living organisms. However, viruses are often present in the human body for long periods of time, and it is possible to study the evolution of viruses in the past by analyzing ancient genetic sequences. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences from humans, which show that the human-infecting parvovirus B19 has been present in humans for a long time. We also show that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is increasing. This is a well-established fact. However, the rate of rise is not constant, and it is not due solely to human activities. The rate of rise is changing, and it is changing because of the climate system. This paper provides a simple, straightforward way to estimate the rate of change in sea level rise. The results are consistent with the conclusions of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) 5th Assessment Report.

Pain is a major public health problem, with a large economic cost. It is also a complex phenomenon, with many causes and many dimensions. In this paper, we focus on one aspect of pain, its prevalence across the life course. We show that, in America today, the elderly report less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is reflected in the erosion of their pain.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach is able to identify the protonation states of the ionizable sites on the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains as well as the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site. The detailed picture of structure and reactivity that emerges from this work highlights the fate of the L-serine hydroxyl leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional view of the reaction mechanism for a key enzyme intermediate. The work also provides a model for how the use of isostere ligands can be used to probe the mechanism of an enzyme. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a zoonotic coronavirus. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. Here, we show that the broad-spectrum antiviral remdesivir, which is already in clinical use, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This suggests that remdesivir may be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This may be of particular importance in the context of the ongoing global pandemic. The data presented here support the conduct of a clinical trial to test the efficacy of remdesivir in MERS. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. (PsycINFO Database Record

The gut microbiota is a major contributor to the health of animals, but the mechanisms by which they interact are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by a host to its symbiotic bacterium is a mechanism for the regulation of the microbiota. This glycan is provided only at night, when the host is quiescent, and is catabolized by the symbiont, which is thus able to maintain a stable population level. This glycan-regulated symbiosis may be a general mechanism for the control of the gut microbiota. (Show more)

This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The findings have implications for the future of education, as well as for the future of the criminal justice system.

Alkylated DNA lesions, induced by both exogenous chemical agents and endogenous metabolites, are major contributors to DNA mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this work, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis on pol II. We found that the transcription of alkylated DNA is controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three alkylation-induced lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe disease in humans. To understand how MERS-CoV infects human cells, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the spike (S) glycoprotein. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings may also be relevant to other coronaviruses. © 2017 International Society for Infectious Diseases. All rights reserved.

The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other health problems. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting can have a large impact on meal selection behavior. This suggests that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in the food system could have a large impact on greenhouse gas emissions and obesity. The results also suggest that it may be possible to nudge people toward more sustainable diets without compromising the catering operation or the health of diners. (Less)

The cell surface is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. This interface is critical for normal cell function, but can also be exploited by cancer cells to promote their growth and survival. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most common oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work will be of interest to the broader cancer research community.

The 2020 presidential election is likely to be the first in which the United States conducts a presidential election using universal vote-by-mail. As such, it is an opportune time to assess the effects of this policy on electoral outcomes. We provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of universal vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be used to increase turnout and is not likely to affect the outcome of elections.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to millions of deaths worldwide. The mechanisms by which the virus causes disease and spreads rapidly are not well understood. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. We show that the structure is similar to that of SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a, but with the addition of two unique interfaces. These interfaces may allow for the formation of unique large-scale assemblies, which could have implications for the immune response and the spread of the virus. This work provides a better understanding of the molecular basis of the COVID-19 disease. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic induction of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the pathophysiology of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema. This study may also provide a new perspective for the study of the pathophysiology of cerebral edema induced by other environmental stresses. (PsycINFO Database Record

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for understanding the strengths and limitations of these methods.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the formation of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs from nonvascular cells is still a challenge. Here, we report the generation of endothelial cells from nonvascular cells using a single transcription factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2). The ETV2-induced endothelial cells (ETVECs) formed mature vascular networks in vivo. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the formation of vascular networks. It also provides a potential therapeutic approach for ischemic disorders. This study will help to understand the mechanism of endothelial development and provide a new strategy for the treatment of ischemic disorders. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between Alk and Ltk with their ligands. We show that the augmentor ligands are essential for zebrafish pigment development and that these ligands are important for the development of iridophores, which are specialized dermal cells that contribute to the coloration of the zebrafish. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a better understanding of the function of these oncogenic receptors and their ligands in vivo. It also provides a model system for studying the function of orphan RTKs in other organisms. This work may also lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches for cancer treatment.

The role of STING in β-cell function and insulin secretion is unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. We also found that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are also the most diverse of all RNA viruses. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and nonspecifically decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides a better understanding of the packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses. It also suggests that the packaging of the influenza A virus genome is more complex than previously thought. (Show more)

The atheroprone disturbed flow is a major risk factor for the development of atherosclerosis. However, the underlying mechanisms are largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the disturbed flow is a key event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atherogenesis and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a rationale for the use of the disturbed flow as a therapeutic target for the prevention of atherosclerosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, the frequency and extent of wildfire in the United States has increased substantially in recent decades, with economic and ecological costs. The expansion of the fire niche by humans is a major driver of this increase. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the geographic and seasonal extent of human-caused wildfires relative to lightning-caused wildfires. Our results highlight the importance of human activities in expanding the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and the need to reduce the risk of wildfire to ecosystems and economies. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should be a focus of United States policy. (Less)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be applied to other cities and to other types of urban change. We hope that our results will inspire further research on the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropod pests remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the avoidance behavior of natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropod pests, and also sheds light on the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This study is of great significance to the sustainable development of pest control. The Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the recent outbreak has prompted global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the time between cell infection and viral production, the rate of viral production, the time a virus-producing cell spends producing virus, and the number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime. We also assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment on the within-host dynamics of ZIKV. Our results can be used to inform the design of clinical trials of antiviral drugs. (Less)

Coral reefs are among the most diverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including global warming. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is one of the most severe consequences of this breakdown. We show that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbionts are a key factor in the onset of the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This may help us to better predict the consequences of environmental change on the stability of coral reefs.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication with the immune system. In this study, we investigate the role of the microbiome in the regulation of the intestinal epithelium. We show that the loss of the microbiome leads to the activation of a tumor-promoting pathway in the intestinal epithelium. We also show that the activation of this pathway leads to the loss of the intestinal barrier, which in turn leads to the activation of the tumor-promoting pathway. Our results identify a mechanism by which the microbiome regulates the activity of the intestinal epithelium. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK pathway to maintain intestinal barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in the regulation of the intestinal epithelium. It also provides a framework for the development of therapeutic strategies to control the activity of the intestinal epithelium. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the main treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients relapse. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 expression was associated with the expression of genes involved in cancer stemness, and that ROR1 expression enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize. Finally, we found that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is marked by a rapid warming and collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet. The cause of this abrupt change is still debated. Here we show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a unique volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a poleward shift of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. This, in turn, led to a rapid warming of the Southern Hemisphere and a collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet.

Freshwater fisheries are a major source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked in conservation and sustainability assessments. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and fishery sustainability. We find that river fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis also reveals that fishing pressure is most intense in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors, highlighting the need for improved management of inland fisheries. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. This analysis is critical for the conservation and sustainable use of inland fisheries. (Less)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The safety of aqueous Li-ion batteries is mainly determined by the negative electrode materials. The development of a safe and high-energy negative electrode material is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The safety of the negative electrode is mainly determined by the surface layer. The unique nanosized and metastable surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of safe and high-energy negative electrode materials. This work is expected to promote the development of safe and high-energy aqueous batteries. The ability to regenerate neurons is a critical feature of the adult nervous system, which is lost in mammals. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway for regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery is important because it provides a platform for the discovery of new factors that regulate neuronal regeneration.

Recombination is a fundamental process in the evolution of genomes. It is also a source of variation in the genetic makeup of organisms. In humans and mice, hotspots of recombination are known to be enriched in the promoter regions of genes. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is enriched in the promoter regions of genes, but also in the coding regions, and that the distribution of recombination is more complex than previously thought. Our results suggest that recombination in plants may be more complex than in animals, and may have been shaped by ancient and conserved mechanisms.

The resting brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to reflect the underlying anatomy and physiology of the brain. However, the exact nature of these networks is still unclear. Here, we used a combination of functional MRI and metabolic imaging to identify and validate the resting organization of the brain. We found that the dominant resting network in healthy subjects is similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network function was assessed by quantifying the expression of the dominant networks in rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant network was deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This study provides a direct measure of the resting organization of the brain, which can be used to assess the function and dysfunction of the brain.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is also involved in mRNA export and stability. Here we describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that NAD-RNA is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on pre-mRNAs, but not on mature mRNAs. This suggests that NAD-RNA could modulate mRNA stability and translation. Our results define a second 5′ modification of mRNA and raise the possibility that the NAD-cap could modulate mRNA function. This could be important for understanding the function of NAD-RNA in the cell. (Show more)

The epigenetic regulation of gene expression is a promising target for the treatment of diabetes complications. We studied the DNA-methylation profile of blood cells from people with diabetes during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT), a landmark study that showed the importance of intensive therapy in preventing complications. We found that the DNA-methylation profile of people with diabetes during the DCCT persists for several years during the follow-up of the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study, which is the long-term follow-up of the DCCT. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also shows that epigenetic changes in blood cells are heritable, as they are transmitted to the next generation. This is an important finding, as it suggests that epigenetic changes are not only heritable in the offspring of people with diabetes, but also in the offspring of people who were treated with intensive therapy during the DCCT.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, suggesting that the gut microbiota may be involved in the development of the disease and in the regulation of the psychological symptoms. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is poorly understood, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit development and flavor is unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the biosynthesis of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also describe the discovery of a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the formation of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles and their role in tomato fruit development and flavor. This knowledge will be useful for the improvement of tomato flavor. (Show more)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a map of local space, which is represented by the activity of grid, head-direction (HD), border, and object-vector (OV) cells. How these cell types are organized in the brain is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to examine the topographic arrangement of neurons in the superficial layers of MEC and adjacent parasubiculum during unrestrained behavior. We found that grid cells exhibited strong coupling among themselves but weaker links to other cell types. These data suggest that grid cell networks might be largely distinct from those of border, HD, and OV cells. Our results provide a detailed view of the organization of the MEC and its connections with other brain regions. They also provide a framework for understanding the formation of the spatial map in the brain. This framework can be applied to other brain areas. The portable two-photon microscope can be used to study the organization of other brain areas. The data presented here can be used to improve the design of portable microscopes for future studies. The data can also be used to improve the design of portable microscopes for future studies.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of the host and the parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model system for studying the evolution of flowering regulation.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing cells of the substantia nigra. The precise nature of the cell-type-specific pathology in this disorder is unknown, but it is thought to involve the loss of specialized synaptic structures, the striosomes. Here, we describe a previously unknown cellular and molecular architecture of the dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons form specialized integrative units, termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” that are likely critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease. These findings have implications for our understanding of the pathophysiology of Parkinson’s disease and other disorders of the dopamine system. They also suggest that bouquet formation is a general feature of the organization of neuronal networks in the brain. (Show more)

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed with which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of how connected they felt. People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This is a fundamental question in social science, and our findings provide a new way to measure it. They also suggest that we may be able to use this signal to improve our social lives.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells are able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. We report here that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN function. We show that STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, and that its deletion leads to depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SAN cells and to a reduction in heart rate. Moreover, we show that STIM1 regulates SAN function by influencing the activity of Ca2+ channels in the plasma membrane of SAN cells. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice. We also show that Si pretreatment promotes the accumulation of Si in rice and enhances the defense response to the rice leaffolder. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the rice defense response to insect herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the function of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based pest management strategies. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to store and integrate information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the passage of time. We show that this mechanism is suitable for binding linguistic features over time, and it can be used to integrate information over time in sequence processing. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we report the successful delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the siRNA-carrying DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the successful delivery of the cargo to the plant cells. We also show that the delivery of the cargo to the plant cells is not dependent on the delivery of the DNA nanostructure into the cells. Our work establishes the feasibility of the delivery of biomolecules to plants using DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. This work will be useful for the development of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies, leaving small tributaries largely unstudied. We show that small tributaries can be a major source of coastal nutrient pollution, especially in large water bodies. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries as a source of coastal nutrient pollution and suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to include these often-overlooked areas. This could help protect valuable nearshore ecosystems and improve the health of lakes and coastal areas worldwide. (Less)

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is difficult to access. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This finding is relevant to the study of the origin of life, as it suggests that the evolution of a network of catalytic reactions may be biased toward the appearance of a few “lucky” chemical configurations that are able to access the environmental forcing.

This study offers a mechanistic understanding of the mechanisms underlying the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain. It provides a framework for understanding the effects of other types of antibodies on the brain. It also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other types of drugs on the brain.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and it is important to understand how the system responds to abrupt warming. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a release of organic matter–derived carbon, which likely enhanced the warming. Our results highlight the importance of understanding the response of the Earth system to abrupt warming events.

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of deforestation-prone tropical peatlands in the world. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification body for palm oil, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase only certified palm oil. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has been unclear. We show that certification reduces deforestation in Indonesia, but that most certified areas still contain substantial forest loss. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having a large impact on deforestation in Indonesia, and that broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results also highlight the importance of certification in forested regions, where deforestation is less severe. These results are important for the palm oil industry, corporations, and governments that are making commitments to sustainable palm oil. They also highlight the importance of certification in reducing tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in the evolution of vertebrates. In many species, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to determine sex. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination genes in a species with four possible sex classes. We find that multiple genes can produce a modular system of sexual variation, which can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species-generating products of photoreceptor metabolism. We sought to understand how the levels of iron, which is a key component of the Fenton reaction, impact the retina. We found that iron levels in retinal pigment epithelial cells, which are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts, impact the levels of reactive oxygen species-generating products of photoreceptor metabolism. These findings have implications for understanding the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, which is a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (PsycINFO Database Record

Siphonophores are a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians that use their tentacles to capture prey. They are considered a model system for studying the evolution of specialization in predators. However, the evolution of specialization in this group has been studied in a single dimension, focusing on the evolution of the morphology of the tentacles. Here we study the evolution of specialization in a second dimension, focusing on the evolution of the nematocysts, the specialized structures that are used to capture prey. We show that the evolution of specialization in this group is not a dead end, and that it is associated with the evolution of the morphology of the tentacles. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is fragmentary, however, and the earliest evidence for the evolution of the derived features of the modern human hand is unknown. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand. The discovery of this fossil also suggests that the evolution of the human hand occurred earlier than previously thought. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the evolution of the genus Homo. (Less)

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a modeling approach to test causal hypotheses, which can be used to test hypotheses in other fields of research. The results are also relevant for the broader field of nutrition and health research, which has largely ignored the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals. (Less)

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for higher output and more efficient production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
